questions.text: A 15-year-old boy was brought to the ER with a nose bleed secondary to trauma. The bleeding started an hour ago and has not stopped. Where is the bleed most likely to be from?
questions.solution:
The bleeding is most likely from the Little's area.

Little’s area, situated at the anteroinferior part of the nasal septum is the most common site of epistaxis in children and young adults.

Factors that increase the risk of epistaxis in children when compared to adults, include the habit of nose picking and increased friability of mucosa due to frequent upper respiratory tract infections.
Little’s area is situated in the anterior inferior part of the nasal septum, just above the vestibule.

questions.text: A worried mother brought her 4-year-old son to the ER with complaints of a nose bleed. On examination, the bleed was found to be from the Kiesselbach’s plexus. Which of the following arteries does not contribute to its formation?
questions.solution:
The posterior ethmoidal artery does not contribute to the formation of Kiesselbach’s plexus.

Kiesselbach’s plexus is the vascular anastomosis situated at Little’s area (anteroinferior part of the septum).

The contributing arteries are as follows:

  • Sphenopalatine and greater palatine branches of the maxillary artery, which in turn is a branch of the external carotid artery.
  • Septal branch of the superior labial artery which in turn is a branch of the facial artery. The facial artery is a branch of the external carotid artery.
  • Anterior ethmoidal branch of the ophthalmic division of internal carotid artery.

The posterior ethmoidal artery is a branch of the ophthalmic division of internal carotid artery, which supplies nasal septum but does not contribute to Kiesselbach’s plexus.

This question was asked in recent AIIMS and NEET examinations, making it a potential repeat.

questions.text: Identify the artery of epistaxis in the given image.
questions.solution:
The structure marked 3 is the sphenopalatine artery which is also known as the artery of epistaxis.

It is called the artery of epistaxis because the majority of the blood supply to the nasal cavity is derived from it. It is also the most commonly involved artery in epistaxis.

Other structures marked in the diagram are as follows:

1 - Anterior ethmoidal artery

2 - Posterior ethmoidal artery

4 - Greater palatine artery

questions.text: Which of the following marked structures is a branch of the internal carotid artery?
questions.solution:
The structure marked 1 is the anterior ethmoidal artery, which is a branch of the ophthalmic division of the internal carotid artery.

Other structures marked in the diagram are as follows:

2 – Sphenopalatine artery

3 – Greater palatine artery

4 – Superior labial artery

2, 3 and 4 are derived from branches of the external carotid artery.

The nasal septum is supplied by branches of both internal and external carotid arteries.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient with a history of uncontrolled, chronic hypertension was rushed to the casualty after he had an episode of coughing out frank blood. On further evaluation, a diagnosis of posterior epistaxis, secondary to hypertension, was made. What is the site of the blood vessel most likely to be involved in this case?
questions.solution:
The most common cause for posterior epistaxis is arterial and the vessel involved is the sphenopalatine artery. It is located in the posterior end of the middle turbinate.

Woodruff's plexus is a venous plexus located in the posterior end of the inferior turbinate and is also sometimes implicated in epistaxis associated with systemic conditions such as hypertension and coagulopathy. However, it only accounts for about 5-10% of all nose bleeds.

Note: Most common vessel involved in both anterior and posterior epistaxis is the sphenopalatine artery and not Woodruff's plexus.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of epistaxis in children?
questions.solution:
Microtrauma due to nose pricking is the most common cause of epistaxis in children.

Other common aetiological associations include upper respiratory tract infections.

Note: In children presenting with recurrent epistaxis, bleeding disorders, hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia, and tumors, etc. have to be ruled out.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of epistaxis in elderly patients?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of epistaxis in elderly patients is idiopthic.

Other causes are: 

  • Trauma
  • Coagulopathy
  • Tumor - high suspicion in elderly patients presenting with epistaxis
  • Infection
  • Medication

Note: Due to the failure of studies to establish a causal relationship between hypertension and epistaxis, hypertension is now considered an associated risk factor and not a cause.

Risk factors associated with epistaxis are weather changes and alcohol consumption.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with persistent unilateral foul-smelling nasal discharge which is blood-stained. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
In a child presenting with persistent unilateral, foul-smelling nasal discharge, which is blood-stained, the most likely cause is a foreign body.

Foreign body can cause unilateral nasal obstruction and subsequent superimposed infection which causes malodorous discharge. It may often be blood-stained. 

Option B: Atrophic rhinitis usually starts at puberty and mainly presents with nasal obstruction and foul smell from the nose. Epistaxis occurs only after the removal of crusts.

Option C: Epistaxis is a rare manifestation of polyps.

Option D: Unilateral nasal angiofibroma also presents as painless, progressive unilateral nasal obstruction, often associated with epistaxis and rhinorrhea. But it is more common in the adolescent age group.

questions.text: What is the maneuver depicted in the image given below?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Trotter’s method in which the patient is made to sit, leaning a little forward over a basin to spit any blood and breathe quietly from the mouth. It is the first step to control epistaxis.

Other options:

Option A: Epley’s maneuver is used in the treatment of BPPV (Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo).

Option C: McGovern’s technique is used in choanal atresia. A feeding nipple with a large hole provides a good oral airway.

Option D: Valsalva maneuver is performed by forceful attempted exhalation against a closed nose and mouth. It is used as a test of cardiac function and autonomic nervous control of the heart, or to clear the ears and sinuses.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman came to the casualty with a history of an episode of spontaneous epistaxis yesterday night. On examination, her BP was 200/110, and there was no active bleeding from the nose. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in managing this case?
questions.solution: The most appropriate next step is observation and blood pressure management as there is no active bleeding from the nose.

questions.text: A 65-year-old hypertensive patient presented with a history of recurrent episodes of spontaneous nose bleeds over the past two weeks, each requiring medical attention. After evaluating the patient, the ENT surgeon recommended endoscopic artery ligation to prevent further episodes. Which of the following arteries is most commonly ligated in this procedure?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of refractory posterior epistaxis. The artery which is most commonly ligated in a case of refractory posterior epistaxis is the sphenopalatine artery.

Posterior epistaxis is most commonly seen in older age groups. The bleeding is spontaneous, often due to hypertension, and is severe, requiring hospitalization. Refractory epistaxis is defined as recurrent or persistent bleeding after appropriate packing or multiple episodes of epistaxis during a short period, each requiring medical attention.

Sphenopalatine artery ligation gives high success in the control of refractory posterior bleed. Therefore, transnasal endoscopic sphenopalatine artery ligation (TESPAL) is the preferred method.

It is ligated at sphenopalatine foramen situated 1 cm behind the posterior end of middle turbinate.

  Anterior epistaxis Posterior epistaxis
Age Children & young adults >40 years
Incidence Most common type Less common
Cause Trauma Spontaneous; often due to Hypertension or arteriosclerosis
Site Little’s area - anteroinferior part of the nasal septum Posterosuperior part of the nasal cavity; difficult to localize
Bleeding Mild- can be controlled by local pressure or nasal packing. Severe-often requires hospitalization and posterior nasal packing.

questions.text: As a first-year resident, you have scrubbed in to assist for a maxillary artery ligation procedure on a patient with intractable epistaxis. After opening the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus, the surgeon asks you to ligate the maxillary artery. Where would you ligate the artery at?
questions.solution:
The maxillary artery is ligated at the pterygopalatine fossa (sphenopalatine fossa) situated behind the maxillary sinus’s posterior wall. 

The internal maxillary artery is accessed transantrally via a Caldwell-Luc approach. After the posterior sinus wall is removed, the internal maxillary artery and its terminal branches are identified and clipped. The posterior sinus wall is then packed with Gelfoam, and the gingivobuccal incision is closed. More recently, transoral and transnasal endoscopic approaches have also been described.

questions.text: Which artery among the following could be the source of bleeding in a case of epistaxis not controlled by external carotid artery ligation?
questions.solution:
Ethmoidal artery can cause epistaxis not controlled by external carotid artery ligation.

The ethmoidal artery is a branch of internal carotid artery, whereas sphenopalatine, greater palatine and facial artery are branches of the external carotid artery. Hence if the bleeding is not controlled by external carotid artery ligation, the subsequent step would be to ligate the ethmoidal artery.

Epistaxis may be classified as anterior or posterior epistaxis.

  Anterior epistaxis Posterior epistaxis
Site Little's area or anterior part of the lateral wall Posterosuperior part of the nasal cavity, or difficult to localize
Age Children, young adults >40 years of age
Cause Usually trauma Spontaneous, due to hypertension or IHD
Bleeding Mild, easily controlled with conservative measures (pressure, anterior nasal pack) Severe requires hospitalisation and posterior nasal pack

Little's area is situated in the anterior inferior part of the nasal septum, just above the vestibule. It is the site of epistaxis in 90% of the cases.

Four arteries anastomose here to form a vascular plexus called the Kiesselbach’s plexus. This area is exposed to the drying effect of inspiratory current and to fingernail trauma and is the usual site for epistaxis in children and young adults.

The four contributing arteries are as follows:

  • Septal branch of sphenopalatine and greater palatine branches of the maxillary artery, which in turn is a branch of the external carotid artery.
  • Septal branch of the superior labial artery which in turn is a branch of the facial artery. The facial artery is a branch of the external carotid artery.
  • Anterior ethmoidal branch of the ophthalmic division of internal carotid artery.

The stepwise management of epistaxis:

  1. Pinching the nose 
  2. Hippocratic or Trotter’s method
  3. Cauterisation
  4. Anterior nasal packing
  5. Posterior nasal packing 
  6. Endoscopic Cauterisation 
  7. Ligation 
  8. Embolization

Ligation should be performed as close as possible to the likely bleeding point. The recommended hierarchy of ligation to be followed is Sphenopalatine artery → Internal maxillary artery → External carotid artery → Anterior /posterior ethmoidal artery.

Ethmoidal vessels are exposed in the medial wall of the orbit by an external ethmoid (Lynch) incision.

questions.text: Which of the following vessels would you never ligate for the control of recurrent spontaneous epistaxis?
questions.solution:
Internal carotid artery is not ligated for controlling epistaxis due to the high percentage of cerebral complications and mortality.

Ligation of the following arteries is done in epistaxis control :

  • Trans nasal Endoscopic Sphenopalatine artery ligation (TESPAL)
  • If not controlled, maxillary artery ligation
  • If still not controlled, external carotid artery ligation
  • In case, bleeding site is superior to the level of middle turbinate, then anterior and posterior ethmoidal vessels should be ligated.
